awd_titl_txt: Influence of Industry-Informed STEM Pathways on Student Experiences and Outcomes in Non-Selective Urban School
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase student motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM). This Industry-Informed STEM Pathways for Students is a project concerned with underrepresentation of people of color and women in STEM fields. It uses a student-centered approach to investigate the ITEST guiding questions related to: motivation and preparedness to pursue STEM careers, instructional and curricular innovations, and partnerships with business and industry. The Boston Plan for Excellence, in collaboration with the Education Development Center and Boston-based STEM industry partners will design, develop, study, and iterate on three industry-informed STEM pathways for 300 students in grades 9-12: electrical engineering, digital design, and computer programming. The significance and importance of the project is large-scale studies of within-school career academies and inclusive STEM high schools that suggest that school-based career pathways may be a promising strategy for boosting STEM career interest and other educational and life outcomes among underrepresented groups. Few interventions to date have attempted to build such pathways within a non-selective school to serve a student population that: (a) includes mostly low-income students of color, many of whom are English learners, (b) has not expressed interest in STEM, and (c) might have gaps in prior STEM knowledge. Therefore, there is little knowledge about how career pathways might be implemented with a wider range of populations, or how components (e.g. coursework, internships) relate to students' interest in and capacity to pursue STEM careers. Moreover, few studies have tracked students over time to understand how their STEM interests and capacity have been shaped by various pathway elements. Informed by research on STEM-focused high schools, career pathways, and social cognitive career theory, this project has the potential to advance knowledge of how schools can develop and sustain STEM interest and capacity among students from underrepresented groups who may have gaps in STEM and/or language preparation. 

Each pathway in electrical engineering, digital design, and computer programming will include an aligned sequence of technology-rich, project-based courses, internships, career talks, company tours, and job readiness workshops. Using design research methodology, the partners will examine the relationships between: (a) career pathway design, (b) students' experiences, and (c) students' STEM interest and capacity within a non-selective, open-enrollment urban public STEM school in Boston. By focusing on the organization of student experiences using a pathway approach, the partners will begin to answer the question: What are the essential components of a successful industry-informed STEM career pathway in a non-selective, urban public STEM school, wherein success results in students graduating with the interest and capacity to fill workforce needs in Boston's STEM-driven economy? The neighborhood-based Dearborn STEM Academy draws a large Cape Verdean and immigrant population from Dorchester and Roxbury., 66% of students are English learners and 75% are from low-income families. Local STEM companies will help design the project, create industry-based experiences for students, and broaden participation in STEM workplaces by youth who are female, Black, Latino, and/or from low-income families. Data collection will include surveying all students each year, as well as multi-year longitudinal data collection (focus groups, observations, classroom assessments) for two student cohorts. Analyses will examine associations between program design and students' STEM interest and capacity. An exploratory quantitative study will be conducted in year three.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Research on Learning in Formal and Informal Settings (DRL)

por.por_cntn:
The two goals of this project were to: (1) develop and refine a set of industry-informed STEM college and career pathways for youth underrepresented in STEM fields, including Black, Latinx, female, and low-income students, and (2) conduct research to inform the development of the pathways and the field. Teachers and administrators at the Dearborn STEM Academy (DSA) worked with industry, nonprofit, and higher education partners to develop and implement pathways in Computer Science, Engineering, and Health & Life Sciences. 

Over the course of the project, 288 unique students in grades 10-12 participated in the pathways, nearly 100 percent of whom were members of one or more groups underrepresented in STEM. 112 DSA students completed at least one early college course, and collectively they completed a total of 286 courses. 62% of the grades earned in these college courses were As or Bs.

This project developed several insights regarding the structures, expertise, and resources needed to develop robust STEM pathways for traditionally underrepresented students. Findings also help illuminate what makes certain pathway components engaging, meaningful, and potentially transformative for students.

1. Developing robust pathways programs requires program development expertise and a clear vision of how the various components of pathways reinforce one another to deliver engaging and impactful learning experiences. At DSA, the Pathways Director and teacher teams articulated a set of design principles that were important to helping ensure that the pathways led to equitable learning experiences for all students. These principles were: (1) relevant and authentic experiences, (2) cultural responsiveness, (3) interdisciplinary curriculum and assessments, (4) industry-connected learning experiences, (5) early college courses, and (6) student support. 

2. Industry Partners are essential resources and play key roles in STEM pathways. First, they can help educators develop an understanding of the knowledge and skills required for success in their industries, and the tools and technologies that are used. Insight from industry is especially useful in ensuring that students' projects are authentic and reflect industry work. Second, industry partners can provide professionals to serve on career panels, coach student teams on their projects, and serve as audiences or judges for demonstrations and presentations. Third, companies can provide internships.

3. Pathway development, refinement, and sustainability require substantial investments of time and resources, both financial and human. Teachers need dedicated time to work in teams and as individuals to engage in ongoing curriculum development, implementation, and adjustment. This work needs to be compensated, scheduled, coordinated, and led. Relationships with industry and higher education partners also need to be managed. 

4. The power of project-based learning to engage students in STEM learning, to build their sense of science self-efficacy, and to help them see connections between their high school work and postsecondary futures appeared to rest on (a) projects' alignment with STEM industry workplace practices, and (b) their interdisciplinary and collaborative nature. In reflecting on project-based learning, many students identified skills they had developed that they believed would be useful in pursuing their future career interests. These included hard skills such as learning a software tool or programming language and soft skills such as teamwork, communication, managing conflict, problem solving, and breaking down work into small parts.

5. Early college is not just about the academic benefits of taking challenging courses and earning college credits but also about developing a college-going identity and a sense of belonging and efficacy, as well as learning how to navigate the very different structures and cultures of higher education. Students from communities underrepresented in higher education and STEM often lack access to knowledge about what it is like to attend college. When they do enroll in college they can thus sometimes struggle to navigate what are often white-dominated, upper middle class, and/or male-dominated spaces. A key goal of early college courses is to introduce students to the structures and expectations of college work while still receiving support from their high school teachers and staff. 

6. Students from underrepresented, low-income communities may need supports to successfully engage with and manage the demands of STEM college and career pathways. Those seeking to develop STEM pathways programs need to consider the new and varied demands (academic, behavioral, sociocultural) that pathways will place on students and identify supports and scaffolding they might need to provide to ensure all students can truly access and engage with the in- and out-of-school experiences that pathways provide. Examples include: pathways teachers working together to coordinate their teaching and assignments to support project-based learning across all their courses; developing common assessments and rubrics for use across all pathways classes; advising students on early college course taking, orienting them to college expectations, and providing tutors or mentors; working closely with partner colleges to monitor the progress of students enrolled in their classes; and offering guidance on how to navigate new types of institutions and, when necessary, code switch. 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2022
Modified by: Edward P Liu
